div1.head: Military Orders for Albert E. Truby, James F. Presnell, and John D. Schweiger, July 25, 1900
div1.p: S

Adjutant General's
OFFICE.
SEP 1 1900
ROLLS DIVISION.
------

ORDERS, BOOKS, BLANKS & D.C. DIV.
A. G. O.
RECD. AUG 18 1900

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 1. }

HEADQUARTERS DEPT. OF WESTERN CUBA,
Quemados, July 25, 1900.

1. 1st Lieutenant William J. Glasgow, 2d Cavalry, late
Captain and Acting Judge Advocate of the Department of
Matanzas and Santa Clara, will proceed to Placetas, Cuba,
on duty connected with the trial of Privates Lyman and
Schaefer, 2d Cavalry, by civil authorities.

Upon completion of this duty Lieutenant Glasgow will
rejoin his present station.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

2. Captain Frederick S. Foltz, 2d Cavalry, will, on com-
pletion of duty at these headquarters, in connection with
the consolidation of the Department of Matanzas and Santa
Clara with the Department of Havana and Pinar del Rio,
return to Matanzas, Cuba, his former station.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

3. 2d Lieutenant L. W. Oliver, 7th Cavalry, will proceed
to Guanajay Barracks, Cuba, for temporary duty as Com-
missary, Quartermaster, and Disbursing Officer of Insular
Funds, and will receipt for all public property and funds
left at that post on departure of the 3d Battalion, 1st In-
fantry, for the United States.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

4. 2d Lieutenant C. F. Armistead, 2d Artillery, will, with
the least practicable delay, proceed to Pinar del Rio Bar-
racks, Cuba, for temporary duty as Commissary and Quar-
termaster, and will receipt for all public property left at
that post on departure of troops.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

5. Major George S. Grimes, 2d Artillery, Acting Inspector
General, will proceed to Guanajay Barracks and Pinar del
Rio Barracks and inspect the accounts of all disbursing
officers located at those points.

Upon completion of the duty ordered Major Grimes will
rejoin his proper station.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

6. The Commanding Officer, Hamilton Barracks, will
supervise all matters of civil administration for the Prov-
ince of Matanzas in so far as is required by existing orders.
He will designate from his command an officer for duty as
Disbursing Officer of Insular Funds, and Inspector of
Schools and Civil Prisons; and also an officer as Inspector
of Hospitals and Charitable Institutions.

Reports will be submitted for the District as required by
Civil Orders No. 29 and No. 54, c. s., Headquarters Divi-
sion of Cuba.

7. The Commanding Officer, Rowell Barracks, will su-
pervise all matters of civil administration in the Province
of Santa Clara in so far as is required by existing orders.
He will designate from his command an officer for duty as
Disbursing Officer of Insular Funds, Inspector of Schools
and Civil Prisons, and Superintendent of Rural Guards;
and also an officer as Inspector of Hospitals and Charitable
Institutions.

Reports will be submitted for the District as required by
Civil Orders No. 29 and No. 54, c. s., Headquarters Divi-
sion of Cuba.

8. Officers on duty at the late Headquarters Department
of Matanzas and Santa Clara will close up the affairs per-
taining to their respective departments, transferring all
property, papers and funds to the proper officers designated
to relieve them, and as soon as practicable thereafter re-
port to their regimental commanders for duty, unless or-
dered elsewhere by proper authority.

The records of that Department will be shipped to these
headquarters.

The Disbursing Officer will transfer to the Disbursing
Officer of Santa Clara any funds on hand pertaining to dis-
bursements to be made in the Province of Santa Clara.

The travel required by this order is necessary for the
public service.

9. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, as
contained in a telegram dated Headquarters Division of
Cuba, July 25, 1900, Hospital Steward Stuart G. Gibboney,
U. S. Army, and Private John Heil, Hospital Corps, U. S.
Army, will proceed from Matanzas, Cuba, to San Francisco,
California, via New Orleans, and will upon arrival at San
Francisco report to the Commanding General, Department
of California.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation, and the Subsistence Department will
commute the rations of the above named enlisted men for
six (6) days, in advance, at the prescribed rate, it being
impracticable to provide rations in kind for that part of the
journey traveled by rail.

10. Upon the recommendation of the Acting Chief Sur-
geon, the following medical officers and enlisted men of the
Hospital Corps, U. S. Army, will accompany the 1st U. S.
Infantry to the United States:

From Pinar del Rio Barracks:
Acting Assistant Surgeon James F. Presnell, U. S.
Army,
Acting Assistant Surgeon Auguste A. Nouel, U. S. Army,
Acting Hospital Steward Edward P. Hammond, U. S.
Army,
Acting Hospital Steward Charles G. Sturtevant, U. S.
Army,
Privates
Orrin Alexander,William W. Clendening,
Clark R. Fosgate,Frank H. Fullington,
Edward Hein,Albert S. Johnson,
Ferreel LeDuc,Augustus W. Legghe,
James McGuire,David McKeown,
Martin Slogan,Noel W. Vaughn.

From Guanajay Barracks:
1st Lieutenant Albert E. Truby, Assistant Surgeon, U.
S. Army,
Hospital Steward Joseph Dykstra, U. S. Army,
Privates
James F. Anderson,August F. Bucholtz,
John R. Flynn,John Gasterland,
Harry M. Ide,Joseph F. O'Brien,
Alexander Stewart,John D. Schweiger.

11. Pursuant to an endorsement dated Headquarters
Division of Cuba, July 24, 1900, a board of survey, to con-
sist of:
Captain E. E. Gayle, 2d Artillery;
Captain George F. Barney, Quartermaster, 2d Artillery;
2d Lieutenant H. W. Schull, 2d Artillery;
will convene at the Signal Office, Division of Cuba, on Fri-
day, July 27th, or as soon thereafter as practicable, to in-
vestigate and report upon the loss of certain signal property
for which Captain Edward B. Ives, Signal Officer, U. S.
Volunteers, reports himself responsible.

12. Pursuant to an endorsement dated Headquarters Di-
vision of Cuba, July 24, 1900, a board of survey, to consist
of:
Captain E. E. Gayle, 2d Artillery;
Captain George F. Barney, Quartermaster, 2d Artillery;
2d Lieutenant H. W. Schull, 2d Artillery;
will convene at the Signal Office, Division of Cuba, on Fri-
day, July 27th, or as soon thereafter as practicable, to in-
vestigate and report upon one typewriter (Smith Premier),
reported by Captain Edward B. Ives, Signal Officer, U. S.
Volunteers, as having been broken in transit between Ha-
vana and Pinar del Rio.

13. 1st Lieutenant S. S. Jordan, 2d Artillery, is hereby
detailed as judge advocate of the general court-martial con-
vened by paragraph 2, Special Orders No. 61, series 1900,
Headquarters Department of Havana and Pinar del Rio,
vice 2d Lieutenant C. F. Armistead, 2d Artillery, relieved.

Lieutenant Armistead will turn over to Lieutenant Jordan
for trial all cases that have been referred to him previous
to this date.

14. Commissary Sergeant John L. Ryan, U. S. Army,
having reported for duty in this Department in compliance
with instructions contained in paragraph 2, Special Orders
No. 144, c. s., Headquarters Department of Matanzas and
Santa Clara, will proceed to Pinar del Rio Barracks, and
report to the commanding officer of that post for duty, re-
lieving 1st Sergeant Reihe, Company F, 1st Infantry, now
Acting Post Commissary Sergeant.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation, the travel directed being necessary for
the public service.

BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL LEE:
R. E. L. MICHIE,
Assistant Adjutant General.
